title: Class properties should/could be inferred from constructor parameters
body:
Hi, this issue is a _following_ of https://twitter.com/psalmphp/status/1133700224168452096.

tl;dr: I was complaining about the tons of `MissingPropertyType` issues I had in classes like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2103975/58555362-8e9da480-8219-11e9-99be-6381890f24f1.png)

I may be wrong, but I think it's common to do this. I mean, not declaring a property type with `@var ...` when a property is directly assigned in the constructor from a PHP-typed parameter.

For example, Symfony [do the same](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/4.4/src/Symfony/Component/Mime/Message.php#L24-L33) since some time with _recent_ code. Also PhpStorm is dealing great with this:
![SÃ©lection_772](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2103975/58556231-c7d71400-821b-11e9-9498-d9ae3ce44a40.png)

Considering [this example](https://psalm.dev/r/dabf4c2e64), when we have `Property Foo::$a does not have a declared type - consider XXX`, it would be nice for Psalm to infer `$a` type with `XXX` instead of giving a warning, no?
That would also prevent the error `Cannot determine the type of the object on the left hand side of this expression`, because for Psalm `$a` has no type.

Here is [the example with `@var`](https://psalm.dev/r/17fc6ab988), this is the behavior I expected before runing Psalm (but without the explicit `@var`).

What do you think about it?
Thanks! :)
